editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Englishmen for my money: or, a pleasant comedy, called, a woman will have her will.
Imprinted at London by W. white, dwelling in Cow-lane. 1616.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: How smug this gray-eyed morning seems to be,
A pleasant sight; but yet more pleasure have I
To think upon this moistening southwest wind,
That drives my laden ships from fertile Spain:
But come what will, no wind can come amiss,
For two and thirty winds that rules the seas,
And blows about this airy region;
Thirty two ships have I to equal them:
Whose wealthy fraughts do make Pisaro rich:
Thus every soil to me is natural:
Indeed by birth, I am a Portingale,
Who driven by western winds on English shore,
Here liking of the soil, I married,
And have three daughters: but impartial death
Long since, deprived me of her dearest life:
Since whose disease, in London I have dwelled:
And by the sweet loud trade of usury,
Letting for interest, and on mortgages.
Do I wax rich, though many gentlemen
By my extortion comes to misery:
Amongst the rest, three English gentlemen,
Have pawned to me their livings and their lands:
Each several hoping, though their hopes are vain,
By marriage of my daughters, to possess
Their patrimonies and their lands again:
But gold is sweet, and they deceive themselves;
For though I guild my temples with a smile,
It is but judas-like, to work their ends.
But soft, what noise of footing do I hear?

div.stage: Enter Laurentia, Marina, Mathea, and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Now master, what intend you to read to us?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Pisaro your father would have me read moral philosophy.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: First tell me how you like it?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: First tell us what it is.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: They be my daughters and their schoolmaster, Pisaro, not a word, but list their talk.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Gentlewomen, to paint philosophy,
Is to present youth with so sour a dish,
As their abhorring stomachs nill digests.
When first my mother Oxford (England's pride)
Fostered me pupil-like, with her rich store,
My study was to read philosophy:
But since, my headstrong youth's unbridled will,
Scorning the leaden fetters of restraint,
Hath pruned my feahers to a higher pitch.
Gentlewomen, moral philosophy is a kind of art,
The most contrary to your tender sexes;
It teacheth to be grave: and on that brow,
Where beauty in her rarest glory shines,
Plants the sad semblance of decayed age:
Those weeds that with their riches should adorn,
And grace fair nature's curious workmanship,
Must be converted to a black faced veil,
Griefs livery, and sorrow's semblance:
Your food must be your hearts abundant sighs,
Steeped in the brinish liquor of your tears:
Daylight as dark-night, dark-night spent in prayer:
Thoughts your companions, and repentant minds,
The recreation of your tired spirits:
Gentlewomen, if you can like this modesty,
Then will I read to you philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Fie upon it.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Hang up philosophy, I'll none of it.

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.p: A tutor said I; a tutor for the devil.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No gentlewomen, Anthony hath learned
To read a lector of more pleasing worth.
Marina, read these lines, young Harvey sent them,
There every line repugns philosophy:
Then love him, for he hates the thing thou hates.
Laurentia, this is thine from Ferdinand:
Think every golden circle that thou seest,
The rich unvalued circle of his worth.
Mathea, with these gloves thy Ned salutes thee;
As often as these, hide these from the sun,
And wanton steals a kiss from thy fair hand,
Presents his serviceable true heart's zeal,
Which waits upon the censure of thy doom:
What though their lands be mortgaged to your father;
Yet may your dowries redeem that debt:
Think they are gentlemen, and think they love;
And be that thought, their true love's advocate.
Say you should wed for wealth; for to that scope
Your father's greedy disposition tends,
The world would say, that you were had for wealth,
And so fair beauties honour quite distinct:
A mass of wealth being powered upon another,
Little augments the show, although the sum;
But being lightly scattered by itself,
It doubles what it seemed, although but one:
Even so yourselves, for wedded to the rich,
His style was as it was, a rich man still:
But wedding these, to wed true love, is duty:
You make them rich in wealth, but more in beauty:
I need not plead that smile, that smile shows hearts consent,
That kiss showed love, that on that gift was lent:
And last thine eyes, that tears of true joy sends,
as comfortable tidings for my friends.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Have done, have done; what needest thou more procure,
When long ere this I stooped to that fair lure:
Thy ever loving Harvey I delight it:
Marina ever loving shall requite it young.
Teach us philosophy? I'll be no nun;
Age scorns delight, I love it being:
There's not a word of this, not a word's part,
But shall be stamped, sealed, printed on my heart;
On this I'll read, on this my senses ply:
All arts being vain, but this philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Why was I made a maid, but for a man?
And why Laurentia, but for Ferdinand?
The chastest soul these angels could entice?
Much more himself, an angel of more price:
Were't thyself present, as my heart could wish,
Such usage thou shouldst have, as I give this.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Then you would kiss him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: If I did, how then?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Nay I say nothing to it, but amen.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: The clerk must have his fees, I'll pay you them.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Good God, how abject is this single life,
I'll not abide it; father, friends, nor kin,
Shall once dissuade me from affecting:
A man's a man; and Ned is more than one:
I faith I'll have thee Ned, or I'll have none;
Do what they can, chafe, chide, or storm their fill,
Mathea is resolved to have her will.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I can no longer hold my patience.
Impudent villainy, and lascivious girls,
I have o'erheard your vild conversions:
You scorn philosophy: you'll be no nun,
You must needs kiss the purse, because he sent it.
And you forsooth, you flurgill, minion,
A brat scant folded in the dozens at most,
You'll have your will forsooth; what will you have?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: But twelve year old? nay father that's not so,
Our sexton told me I was three years more.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I say but twelve: you're best tell me I lie.
What sirrah Anthony.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Come here sir, and you light huswives get you in:
Stare not upon me, move me not to ire:Exeunt sisters.
Nay sirrah stay you here, I'll talk with you:
Did I retain thee (Villain) in my house,
Gave thee a stipend twenty marks by year,
And hast thou thus infected my three girls,
Urging the love of those, I most abhorred;
Unthrifts, beggars; what is worse,
And all because they are your countrymen?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Why sir, I taught them not to keep a merchant's book, or cast account: yet to a word much like that word account.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A knave passed grace, is past recovery.
Why sirrah Frisco, villain, loggerhead, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Here's a calling indeed; a man were better to live a lord's life and do nothing, than a serving creature, and never be idle. O master, what a mess of brewis stands now upon the point of spoiling by your hastiness; why they were able to have got a good stomach with child even with the sight of them; and for a vapour, o precious vapour, let but a wench come near them with a painted face, and you should see the paint drop and curdle on her cheeks, like a piece of dry Essex cheese toasted at the fire.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sirrah, leave this thought, and mind my words,
Give diligence, inquire about
For one that is expert in languages,
A good musician, and a Frenchman born;
And bring him hither to instruct my daughters,
I'll ne'er trust more a smooth-faced Englishman.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
What, must I bring one that can speak languages?
what an old ass is my master; why he may speak flaunt taunt as well as French, for I cannot understand him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: If he speak French, thus he will say, awee awee:
What, canst thou remember it?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O, I have it now, for I remember my great grandfathers grandmothers sisters cousin told me, that pigs and Frenchmen, speak one language, awee awee; I am dog at this: but what must he speak else?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Dutch.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Let's hear it?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Haunce butterkin slowpin.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O this is nothing, for I can speak perfect Dutch when I list.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Can you, I pray let's hear some?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay I must have my mouth full of meat first, and then you shall hear me grumble it forth full mouth, as Haunce butterkin slowpin frokin: no, I am a simple Dutchman: well, I'll about it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Stay sirrah, you are too hasty; for he must speak one language more.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: More languages? I trust he shall have tongues enough for one mouth: but what is the third?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Italian.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why that is the easiest of all, for I can tell whether he have any Italian in him even by looking on him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Can you so, as how?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry by these three points; a wanton eye. Pride in his apparel, and the devil in his countenance. Well, God keep me from the devil in seeking this Frenchman: but do you hear me master, what shall my fellow Anthony do, it seems he shall serve for nothing but to put Latin into my young mistresses.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hence ass, hence loggerhead, begone I say.
And now to you that reads philosophy,
Pack from my house, I do discharge thy service,
And come not near my doors; for if thou dost,
I'll make thee a public example to the world.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well crafty fox, you that work by wit,
It may be, I may live to fit you yet.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, this trick was spied in time,
For if but two such lectures more they'd heard,
For ever had their honest names been marred:
I'll in and rate them: yet that's not best,
The girls are wilful, and severity
May make them careless, mad, or desperate.
What shall I do? Oh! I have found it now,
There are three wealthy merchants in the town,
All strangers, and my very special friends,
The one of them is an Italian:
A Frenchman, and a Dutchman, be the other:
These three intyrely do affect my daughters,
And therefore mean I, they shall have the tongues,
That they may answer in their several language:
But what helps that? they must not stay so long,
For whiles they are a learning languages,
My English youths, both wed, and bed them too:
Which to prevent, I'll seek the strangers out,
Let's look: 'tis past eleven, exchange time full,
There shall I meet them, and confer with them,
This work craves haste, my daughters must be wed,
For one months stay, say farewell maiden head.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, we're almost at the house,
I promise you this walk o'er tower-hill,
Of all the places London can afford,
Hath sweetest air, and fitting our desires.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Good reason, so it leads to croched-fryers
Where old Pisaro, and his daughters dwell,
Look to your feet, the broad way leads to hell:
They say hell stands below, down in the deep,
I'll down that hill, where such good wenches keep,
But sirrah Ned, what says Mathea to thee?
Wilt fadge? wilt fadge? What, will it be a match?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: A match say you? A mischief 'twill as soon:
Should I can scarce begin to speak to her,
But I am interrupted by her father.
Ha, what say you? and then put o'er his snout,
Able to shadow Paul's, it is so great.
Well, 'tis no matter, sirs, this is his house,
Knock for the churl bid him bring out his daughter;
I'll, 'sblood I will, though I be hanged for it,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda, nothing with you but up and ride,
You'll be within, ere you can reach the door,
And have the wench, before you compass her:
You are too hasty, Pisaro is a man,
Not to be fed with words, but won with gold.
But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Whom, Anthony our friend?
Say man, how fares our loves? How doth Mathea?
Can she love Ned? how doth she like my suit?
Will old Pisaro take me for his son;
For I thank God, he kindly takes our lands,
Swearing, good gentlemen you shall not want,
Whilst old Pisaro, and his credit holds:
He will be damned the rogue, before he do't?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Prithee talk milder: let but thee alone,
And thou in one bare hour will ask him more,
Than he'll remember in a hundred years:
Come from him Anthony, and say what news?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: The news for me is bad; and this it is:
Pisaro hath discharged me of his service.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Discharged thee of his service; for what cause?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Nothing, but that his daughters learn philosophy.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Maids should read, that it teacheth modesty.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Ay, but I left out mediocrity,
And with effectual reasons, urged your loves.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: The fault was small, we three will to thy master
And beg thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: O, that cannot be,
He hates you far worser, than he hates me;
For all the love he shows, is for your lands,
Which he hopes sure will fall into his hands:
Yet gentlemen, this comfort take of me,
His daughters to your loves affected be:
Their father is abroad, they three at home,
Go cheerly in, and cease that is your own:
And for myself, but grace what I intend,
I'll overreach the churl, and help my friend.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Build on our helps, and but devise the means.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Pisaro did command Frisco his man,
(A simple sot, kept only but for mirth)
To inquire about in London for a man,
That were a Frenchman and musician,
To be (As I suppose) his daughter's tutor:
Him if you meet, as like enough you shall,
He will inquire of you of his affairs;
Then make him answer, you three came from Paul's,
And in the middle walk, one you espied,
Fit for his purpose; then describe this cloak,
This beard and hat: for in this borrowed shape,
Must I beguile and overreach the fool:
The maids must be acquainted with this drift.
The door doth open, I dare not stay reply,
Lest being descried: gentlemen adieu,
And help him now, that oft hath helped you.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: How now sirrah, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whither am I going, how shall I tell you, when I do not know myself, nor understand myself?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry sir, I am seeking a needle in a bottle of hay, a monster in the likeness of a man: one that in stead of good morrow, asketh what porridge you have to dinner, parley vous signior? one that never washes his fingers, but licks them clean with kisses; a clipper of the King's English: and to conclude, an eternal enemy to all good language.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: What's this? what's this?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Do not you smell me? Well, I perceive that wit doth not always dwell in a satin-doublet: why, 'tis a Frenchman, Bassimon cue, how do you?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: I thank you sir, but tell me what wouldst thou do with a Frenchman:

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay faith, I would do nothing with him, unless I set him to teach parrots to speak: marry the old ass my master, would have him to teach his daughters, though I trust the whole world sees, that there be such in his house that can serve his daughter's turn, as well as the proudest Frenchman: but if you be good lads, tell me where I may find such a man?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: We will, go hie thee straight to Paul's,
There shalt thou find one fitting thy desire;
Thou soon mayst know him, for his beard is black,
Such is his raiment, if thou runnest apace,
Thou canst not miss him frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Lord, lord, how shall poor Phrisco reward your rich tidings gentlemen: I am yours till Shrove-tuesday, for then change I my copy, and look like nothing but red-herring cobs, and stockfish; yet I'll do somewhat for you in the mean time: my master is abroad, and my young mistresses at home: if you can do any good on them before the Frenchman corn, why so? Ah gentlemen, do not suffer a litter of languages to spring up amongst us: I must to the walk in Paul's, you
to the vestry. Gentlemen, as to myself, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Fool's tell the truth men say, and so may he:
Wenches we come now, love our conduct be.
Ned, knock at the door: but soft forbear;
The cloud breaks up, and our three suns appear.
To this I fly, shine bright my lives sole stay,
And make grief's night a glorious summer's day.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Gentlemen, how welcome you are here,
Guess by our looks, for other means by fear
Prevented is: our father's quick return
Forbids the welcome, else we would have done.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Mathea, how these faithful thoughts obey,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No more sweet love, I know what thou wouldst say:
You say you love me, so I wish you still,
Love hath love's hire, being balanced with good will:
But say; come you to us, or come you rather
To pawn more lands for money to our father?
I know 'tis so, a god's name spend at large:
What man? our marriage day will all discharge;
Our father (By his leave) must pardon us,
Age save of age, of nothing can discuss:
But in our loves, the proverb we'll fulfil ▪
Women and maids, must always have their will.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Say thou as much, and add life to this corse,

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Yourself and your good news doth more enforce:
How these have set forth love by all their wit,
I swear in heart, I more than double it.
Sisters be glad, for he hath made it plain,
The means to get our schoolmaster again:
But gentlemen, for this time cease our loves,
This open street perhaps suspicion moves,
Fain we would stay, bid you walk in more rather,
but that we fear the coming of our father:
Go to th' exchange, crave gold as you intend,
Pisaro scrapes for us; for us you spend:
We say farewell, more sadlier be bold,
Then would my greedy father to his gold:
We here, you there, ask gold; and gold you shall:
We'll pay the interest, and the principal. Exeunt sisters

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: That's my good girls, and I'll pay you for all.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Come to th' exchange, and when I feel decay,
Send me such wenches, heavens I still shall pray.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Delion the Frenchman, Vandal the Dutchman, Aluaro the italian, and other merchants, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Good morrow, m. strangers.

sp.speaker: Strang.
sp.p: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: This (Loving friends) hath thus emboldened me,
For knowing the affection and the love
Master Vandal, that you bear my daughter:
Likewise, and that with joy considering too,
You monsieur Delion, would fain dispatch ▪
I promise you, methinks the time did fit,
And does by’r lady too, in mine advice,
This day to clap a full conclusion up:
And therefore made I bold to call on you,
Meaning (Our business done here at the burse)
That you at mine entreaty should walk home,
And take in worth such viands as I have:
And then we would, and so I hope we shall,
Loosely tie up the knot that you desire,
But for a day or two; and then church rites
Shall sure conform, confirm, and make all fast.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Seker mester Pisaro, me do so groterly dank you, dat you macke me so sure of de wench, datt ic can neit dank you genough.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p:
Monsieur Pisaro, mon pere, mon vadere, o de
grande joy you give me (Oconte) me sal go home to your house, sal eat your bacon, sal eat your beef, and shall tack de wench, de fine damoysella.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You shall, and welcome ▪ welcome as my soul:
But were my third son sweet Alvaro here,
We would not stay at the exchange today,
But hie us home and there end our affairs.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.p: Good day master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Master Moore, marry with all my heart good morrow sir; what news? What news?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.p: This merchant here my friend, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: Sir, this jolly south-west wind with gentle blast,
Hath driven home our long expected ships,
All laden with the wealth of ample Spain,
And but a day is past since they arrived
Safely at Plymouth, where they yet abide.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thanks is too small a guerdon for such news.
How like you this news friends? Master Vandal,
Here's somewhat towards for my daughter's dowry:
Here's somewhat more than we did yet expect.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But hear you sir, my business is not done;
From these same ships I did receive these lines,
And there enclosed this same bill of exchange,
To pay at sight; if so you please accept it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Accept it, why? What sir should I accept,
Have you received letters, and not I?
Where is this lazy villain, this slow post:
What, brings he every man his letters home,
And makes me nobody ; does he, does he?
I would not have you bring me counterfeit;
And if you do, assure you I shall smell it:
I know my factors writing well enough.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: You do sir; then see your factor's writing:
I scorn as much as you, to counterfeit,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: 'Tis well you do sir.
What master walgrave, and my other friends:
You are grown strangers to Pisaro's house,
I pray make bold with me.

sp.speaker: Walsg.
sp.l: Ay, with your daughters
You may be sworn, we'll be as bold as may be.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Would you have ought with me, I pray now speak.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Sir, I think you understand our suit,
By the repairing we have had to you:
Gentlemen you know, must want no coin,
Nor are they slaves unto it, when they have:
You may perceive our minds; what say you to't?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Gentlemen all ▪ I love you all:
Which more to manifest, this afternoon
Between the hours of two and three repair to me;
And were it half the substance that I have,
Whilst it is mine, 'tis yours to command.
But gentlemen, as I have regard to you,
So do I wish you'll have respect to me:
You know that all of us are mortal men,
Subject to change and mutability;
You may, or I may, soon pitch o'er the perch ▪
Or so, or so, have contrary crosses:
Wherefore I deem but mere equity,
That some thing may betwixt us be to show.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, within this two months without fail,
We will repay.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: God save you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gentlemen.
sp.p: Good morrow sin.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What m. brown, the only man I wished for,
Does your price fall? what shall I have these clothes?
For I would ship them straight away for Stoade:
I do wish you my money fore another.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: Faith you know my price sir, if you have them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You are too dear in sadness, master Heigham:
You were about to say somewhat, pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Then this it was: those lands that are not mortgaged

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: God bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.p: I must crave pardon; o sirrah, are you come?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda; what's the matter now;
Sure, yonder fellow will be torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: What's he, sweet youths; that so they flock about:
What old Pisaro tainted with this madness?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Upon my life, 'tis somebody brings news;
The court breaks up, and we shall know their counsel:
Look, look, how busily they fall to reading.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am the last ▪ you should have kept it still:
Well, we shall see what news you bring with you;
sp.p: Our duty premised, and we have sent unto your worship sack, seville oils, pepper, Barbery sugar, and such other commodities as we thought most requisite, we wanted money therefore we are fain to take up 200. l. of master towersons man, which by a bill of exchange sent to him, we would request your worship pay accordingly. You shall command sir, you shall command sir, the news here is, that the English ships, the fortune, your ship, the adventure and good luck of London coasting along by Italy towards Turkey, were set upon by to spanish-galleys, what became of them we know not, but doubt much by reason of the weather's calmness.

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: How is't six to one the weather calm,
Now afore God who would not doubt their safety,
A plague upon these spanish-galley pirates,
roaring Charybdis, or devouring Scylla,
Were half such terror to the antic world,
As these same antic villains now of late,
Have made the straits twixt Spain and Barbary.

sp.speaker: Tower
sp.p: Now sir, what doth your factor's letters say?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry he saith, these witless luckless dolts,
Have met, and are beset with Spanish galleys,
As they did sail along by Italy:
What a bot's made the dolts near Italy,
Could they not keep the coast of Barbary,
Or having passed it, gone for Tripoli,
Being on the other side of Sicily,
As near, as where they were unto the straits:
For by the globe, both Tripoli and it,
Lie from the straits some twenty five degrees;
And each degree makes threescore English miles?

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.p: Very true sir: but it makes nothing to my bill of exchange: this dealing fits not one of your account.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And what fits yours? A prating wrangling tongue,
A woman's ceaseless and incessant babbling,
That sees the world turned topsy turvy with me;
Yet hath not so much wit to stay a while,
Till I bemoan my late excessive loss.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'Swounds 'tis dinner time, I'll stay no longer:
Hark you a word sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I tell you sir, it would have made you whine
Worse then if shools of luckless croaking ravens,
Had ceased on you to feed their famished paunches:
Had you heard news of such a ravenous rout,
Ready to cease on half the wealth you have.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: 'Sblood you might have kept at home and be hanged,
What a pox care I.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: God save your worship, a little money and so forth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But men are senseless now of others woe,
This stony age is grown so stony hearted,
That none respects their neighbours' miseries,
I wish (As poets do) that Saturn's times
The long out worn world wear in use again,
That men might sail without impediment.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I marry sir that were a merry world indeed, I would hope to get more money of your worship in one quarter of a year, than I can do now in a whole twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: Master Pisaro how I have run about,
How I have toiled today to find you out,
At home, abroad, at this man's house, at that,
Why I was here an hour ago and more,
Where I was told you were, but could not find you.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Faith sir I was here but was driven home,
Here's such a common haunt of crackrope boys,
That what for fear to have m'apparell spoilt,
Or my ruffs dirted, or eyes struck out:
I dare not walk where people do expect me:
Well, things (I think) might be better looked unto,
And such coin to, which is bestowed on knaves,
Which should, but do not see things be reformed,
Might be employed to many better uses:
But what of beardless boys, or such like trash;
The Spanish galleys: o, a vengeance on them.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Mass, this man hath the luck on't, I think I can scarce ever come to him for money, but this a vengeance on, and that a vengeance on't, doth so trouble him, that I can get no coin: well, a vengeance on't for my part; for he shall fetch the next letters himself.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: I prithee, when thinkst thou the ships will be come about from Plymouth?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Next week, sir.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Came you sir from Spain lately?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Ay sir; why ask you that?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Marry sir, thou seems to have been in the hot countries, thy face looks so like a piece of rusty bacon: had thy host at Plymouth meat enough in the house, when thou wert there?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: What though he had not sir? but he had, how then?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry thank God for it; for otherwise, he would doubtless have cut thee out in rashers to have eaten thee; thou lookest as thou wert through broiled already.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: You have said sir; but I am no mere for his moing, nor yours neither: if I had you in place where, you should find me tough enough in digestion, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Walgr,
sp.p: What will you swagger sirrah, will ye swagger?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: I beseech you sir, hold your hand; get home ye patch, cannot you suffer gentlemen jest with you?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I'd teach him a gentle trick and I had him of the burse; but I'll watch him a good turn I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Assure ye master Towerson, I cannot blame him,
I warrant you it is no easy loss;
How think you master stranger? by my faith sir,
There's twenty merchants will be sorry for it,
That shall be partners with him in his loss.

sp.speaker: Strangers
sp.p: Why sir, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: The spanish-galleys have beset our ships,
That lately were bound out for Siria.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: What not? I promise you I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What an old ass is this to keep us here:
Master Pisaro, pray dispatch us hence.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Master Vandal I confess I wrong you;
But I'll but talk a word or two with him, and straight turn to you.
Ah sir, and how then y faith?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Turn to us, turn to the gallows if you will,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: 'Tis midsummer-moon with him: let him alone,
He calls Ned walgrave, master Vandal.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Let it be shrovetide, I'll not stay an inch master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What should you fear: end as I have vowed before,
So now again; my daughters shall be yours:
And therefore I beseech you and your friends,
Defer your business till dinner time;
And what you'd say, keep it for table talk.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Marry and shall; a right good motion:
Sirs, old Pisaro is grown kind of late,
And in pure love, hath bid us home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Good news in truth: but wherefore art thou sad?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: For fear the slave ere it be dinner time,
Remembering what he did, recall his word:
For by his idle speeches, you may swear,
His heart was not confederate with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Tut never doubt, keep stomachs till anon,
And then we shall have cates to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sir, since things do fall so crossly out,
I must dispose myself to patience:
But for your business, do you assure yourself,
At my repairing home from the exchange,
I'll set a helping hand unto the same.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bon iurno signeour padre, why be de melancholy so much, and grave in you a: what news make you look so naught?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Naught is too good an epithet by much,
For to distinguish such contrariousness:
Hath not swift fame told you our slow sailed ships
Have been o'ertaken by the swift sail galleys,
And all my cared-for goods within the lurch
Of that same caterpillar brood of Spain.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signior si, how de spaniola have almost tack de ship dat go for Turkey: my pader, hark you me on word, I have receive un lettre from my factor de Vennise, dat after un piculo battalion, for un half hour de come a wind fra de North, and de sea go tumble here, and tumble dare, dat make de galleys run away for fear be almost drowned.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How sir; did the wind rise at North, and seas wax rough: and were the galleys therefore glad to fly?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.p: Signior si, and de ship go drite on de Iscola de Candy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Wert thou not my Alvaro my beloved,
One whom I know does dear count of me,
Much should I doubt me that some scoffing lack,
Had sent thee in the midst of all my griefs,
To tell a feigned tale of happy luck.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Will you no believe me? see dare dan, see de lettre.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What is this world? or what this state of man,
How in a moment cursed, in a trice blessed?
But even now my happy state 'gan fade,
And now again, my state is happy made,
My goods all safe, my ships all scaped away,
And none to bring me news of such good luck,
But whom the heavens have marked to be my son:
Were I a lord as great as Alexander,
None should more willingly be made mine heir
Than thee thou golden tongue, thou good-news teller
Joy stops my mouth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, the day is late, the bell doth ring:
Wilt please you hasten to perform this business?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What business sir? God's me, I cry you mercy:
Do it, yes sir, you shall command me more.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But sir, what do you mean, do you intend
To pay this bill, or else to palter with me?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry God shield, that I should palter with you:
I do accept it, and come when you please;
You shall have money, you shall have your money due.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I beseech your worship to consider me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: O, you cannot cog: go to, take that,
Pray for my life: pray that I have good luck,
And thou shalt see, I will not be thy worst master.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Marry God bless your worship; I came in happy time: what, a French crown? sure he knows not what he does: well, I'll begone, lest he remember himself, and take it from me again.

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: Come on my lads, m. Vandal, sweet son Alvaro:
come don Balsaro, let's be jogging home
By'r lakin sirs, I think 'tis one o'clock .

div.stage: Extt Pisaro, Balsaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandal.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Come m. Moore, th'exchange is waxen thin,
I think it best we get us home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: I know that I am looked for long ere this:
Come master Towerson, let's walk along.

div.stage: Exit Moore, Brovvne, Towerson, strangers, and merchant.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And if you be so hot upon your dinner,
Your best way is, to haste Pisaro on,
For he is cold enough, and slow enough;
He hath so late digested such cold news.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Marry and shall: hear you master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Many Pisaro's here: why how now Ned;
Where is your Matt your welcome, and good cheer?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: 'Swounds, let's follow him; why stay we here?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay prithee Ned Walg. let's bethink ourselves,
There's no such haste, we may come time enough:
At first Pisaro bade us come to him
Twixt two or three o'clock at afternoon ?
Then was he old Pisaro: but since then,
What with his grief for loss, and joy for finding,
He quite forgot himself, when he did bid us,
And afterwards forgot, that he had bade us.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I care not, I remember't well enough:
He bade us home; and I will go, that's flat,
To teach him better wit another time.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Here'll be a gallantiest, when we come there,
To see how mazed the greedy chuff will look
Upon the nations, sects, and factions,
That now have born him company to dinner:
But hark you, let's not go to vex the man;
Prithee sweet Ned let's tarry, do not go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Not go? indeed you may do what you please;
I'll go, that's flat: nay, I am gone already,
stay you two, and consider further of it.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay all will go, if one: I prithee stay;
Thou'rt such a rash and giddy headed youth,
Each stone's a thorn: hoyda, he skips for haste;
Young Harvey did but jest; I know he'll go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay, he may choose for me: but if he will,
Why does he not? why stands he prating still?
If you'll go, come: if not, farewell?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Higher a post-horse for him (Gentle Francke)
Here's haste, and more haste than a hasty pudding:
You madman, madcap, wild-oats; we are for you,
It boots not stay, when you intend to go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Come away then.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandal.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A thousand welcomes friends: monsieur Delion,
Ten thousand ben-venues unto yourself.
Signior Alvaro, master Vandal;
Proud am I, that my roof contains such friends.
Why mall, Larentia, Matth; where be these girls?
Lively my girls, and bid these strangers welcome;
They are my friends, your friends, and our well-willers:
You cannot tell what good you may have on them.
God's me, why stir you not? Hark in your ear,
These be the men the choice of many millions,
That I your careful father have provided
To be your husbands: therefore bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Nay by my troth, 'tis not the guise of maids,
To give a slavering salute to men:Aside,
If these sweet youths have not the wit to do it,
We have the honesty to let them stand.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: God's sekerlin, dats un-fra meskin, monsieur Delion dare de groat freisler, dare wode ic zene, 'tis un-fra daughter, dare heb ic so long loud, dare heb my desire so long gewest.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Ah Venice, Roma, Italia ▪ Frauncia, anglitera, nor all dis orb can show so much belliza, veremante de secunda, madonade granda beauty.

sp.speaker: Delio
sp.p: Certes me dincke de mine depeteta de little Angloise, de me matresse Pisaro is un net, un becues, un fra, et un tendra damosella.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What stocks, what stones, what senseless trunks be these?
Whenas I bid you speak, you hold your tongue:
When I bid peace, then can you prate, and chat,
And gossip: but go too, speak and bid welcome;
Or (As I live) you were as good you did.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I cannot tell what language I should speak:
If I speak English (As I can none other)
They cannot understand me, nor my welcome.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bella madonna, dare is no language so dulce; dulce, dat is sweet, as de language, dat you shall speak, and de vell come dat you sal say, sal be well know perfaytemente.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Pray sir, what is all this in English?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: De usa sal vell teash you vat dat is; and if you sal please, I will teash you to parlour italiano.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And that methinks sir, not without need:
And with Italian, to a child's obedience,
With such desire to seek to please their parents,
As others far more virtuous than themselves,
Do daily strive to do: but 'tis no matter,
I'll shortly pull your haughty stomachs down:
I'll teach you urge your father; make you run,
When I bid run: and speak, when I bid speak:
What greater cross can careful parents haveKnock within
Then careless children. Stir and see who knocks?

sp.speaker: Walgr.
sp.p: Good morrow to my good mistress Mathea.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: As good a morrow, to the morrow giver.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: A murrain, what make these? What do they here?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: You see master Pisaro, we are bold guests ▪
You could have bid no surer men than we.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hark you gentlemen; I did expect you
At afternoon , not before two o'clock .

sp.speaker: Haru,
sp.p: Why sir, if you please, you shall have us here at two o'clock , at three o'clock , at four o'clock ; nay till tomorrow this time: yet I assure you ▪ sir, we came not to your house without inviting.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why gentlemen, I pray who bade you now?
Whoever did it, sure hath done you wrong:
For scarcely could you come to worser cheer.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: It was your own self bade us to your cheer,
When you were busy with Balsaro talking;
You bade us cease our suits till dinner time,
And then to use it for our table talk:
And we I warrant you, are as sure as steel.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A murrain on yourselves, and sureness too:
How am I crossed: god's me, what shall I do,
This was that ill news of the Spanish pirates,
That so disturbed me: well, I must dissemble,
And bid them welcome; but for my daughters
I'll send them hence, they shall not stand and prate.
Well my masters, gentlemen, and friends,
Though unexpected, yet most heartily welcome;
(Welcome with a vengeance) but for your cheer,
That will be small: yet too too much for you.
Mall, in and get things ready.
Laurentia, bid Maudlin lay the cloth, take up the meat:
Look how she stirs; you sullen elf, you callet,
Is this the haste you make?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signior Pisaro, ne soiat so malcontento de gentlewoman your filigola did parlour but a litella to, de gentle homa y our grand amico.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But that grand amico, is your grand inimico:
One, if they be suffered to parlar,
will poll you, I and pill you of your wife:
They love together: and the other two,
Loves her two sisters: but 'tis only you
Shall crop the flower, that they esteem so much.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Do they so; vell let me lone, sal see me give dem de such grand mock, sal be shame of demselves .

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Do sir, I pray you do; set lustily upon them,
And I'll be ready still to second you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: But Matt, art thou so mad as to turn French?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Yes marry when two Sundays come together;
Think you I'll learn to speak this gibberish,
Or the pig's language? Why, if I fall sick,
They'll say, the French (Etcetera) infected me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now minion; what, is this your service?
Your other sisters busy are employed,
And you stand idle: get you in, or.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: If you chide her, chide me (M. Pisaro:
For but for me, she had gone in long since.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I think she had: for we are sprights to scare her;
But ere't be long, I'll drive that humour from her.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signior, me thinks you soud no macke de when she so hardee, so disobedient to de padre as ditt madonna Matt.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Signior, methinks you should learn to speak, before you should be so foolhardy, as to woe such a maiden as that madonna Matt?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Warrent you monsieur, he sal parley wen you sal stand out the dour.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Hark you monsieur, you would wish yourself half hanged, you were as sure to be let in as he.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Macke no doubt de signior Alva. sal do vel enough

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Perhaps so: but methinks your best way were to ship yourself for stoad, and there to batter yourself for a commodity; for I can tell you, you are here out of liking.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: The worst perhaps dislike him, but the best esteem him best.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: But by your patience sir, methinks none should know better who's lord, than the lady.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Den de lady, vat lady?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry sir, the lady let her alone: one that means to let you alone for fear of trouble.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Every man as he may: yet sometimes the blind may catch a hare.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Ay sir, but he will first eat many a fly:
You know it must be a wonder, if a crab catch a fowl.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Maer hortens; if he and ic and monsieur Delion be de crab, we sal kash de foul well genough, I warrent you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Ay, and the fool well enough I warrant you;
And much good may it do ye.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Me dincke such a piculo man as you be, sal have no de such grande luck madere.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Non da monsieur, and he be so granda amorous op de damosella, he sal have Mawdlyn de wit wench in de kitchen by matter Pisaro's leave.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: By m. Pisaro's leave, Monsieur I'll mumble you, except you learn to know, whom you speak to: I tell thee Francois, I'll have (Maugre thy teeth) her that shall make thee gnash thy teeth to want.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Yet a man may want of his will, and bate an ace of his wish: but gentlemen, every man as his luck serves, and so agree we; I would not have you fall out in my house: come, come, all this was in jest, now let's to't in earnest; I mean with our teeth, and try who's the best trencherman.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Ah sirrah, now I know, what manner of thing Paul's is; I did so mar'le afore what it was out of all count: for my master would say, would I had Paul's full of gold. My young mistresses, and Grimkin our tailor, would wish they had Paul's full of needles: ay, one asked my master half a yard of freeze to make me a coat and
he cried whoop holiday, it was big enough to make Paul's a nightgown. I have been told, that Duke Humphrey dwells here, and that he keeps open house, and that a brave sort of cammileres dine with him every day; now if I could see any vision in the world towards dinner, I would set in a foot: but the best is, a the ancient English roman orator saith, so-lame-men, misers, housewives, and so forth: the best is, that I have great store of company that do nothing but go up and down, and go up and down, and make a grumbling together, that the meat is so long making ready: well, if I could meet this scurvy Frenchman, they should stay me, for I would be gone home.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I beseech you monsieur, give me audience.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What would you have? What should I give you?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Pardon, sir mine uncivil and presumptuous intrusion, who endeavour nothing less, than to provoke or exasperate you against me.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: They say, a word to the wise is enough: so by this little French that he speaks, I see he is the very man I seek for: sir, I pray what is your name?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I am nominated monsieur le mouche, and rest at your bon service.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I understand him partly; yea, and partly nay: can you speak French? Content poor vous monsieur Madomo.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: If I could not sir, I should ill understand you: you speak the best French that ever trodden upon shoe of leather.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay, I can speak more languages than that: this is Italian, is it not? Nella slurde curtezana .

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, and you speak it like a very natural.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: I believe you well ▪ now for Dutch:
Ducky de do watt heb ye goe brought.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I pray stop your mouth, for I never heard such Dutch before brought.

sp.speaker: Frsc.
sp.p: Nay I think you have not met with no peasant: hear you m. mouse, (So your name is I take it) I have considered of your learning in these aforesaid languages, and find you reasonable: so, so, now this is the matter; can you take the ease to teach these tongues to two or three gentlewomen of mine acquaintance, and I will see you paid for your labour.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, and that most willingly.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why then m. mouse, to their use, I entertain ye, which had not been but for the troubles of the world, that I myself have no leisure to show my skill: well sir, if you'll please to walk with me, I'll bring you to them.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.l: Sit till dinners done; not I, I swear:
Shall I stay? till he belch into mine ears
Those rustic phrases, and those Dutch French terms,
Stammering half sentences dogbolt eloquence:
And when he hath no love forsooth, why then
He tells me cloth is dear at Antwerp, and the men
Of Amsterdam have lately made a law,
That none but Dutch as he, may traffic there:
Then stands he still and studies what to say;
And after some half hour, because the ass
Hopes (As he thinks) I shall not contradict him.
He tells me that my father brought him to me,
And that I must perform my father's will.
Well goodman Goosecap, when thou woo'st again,
Thou shalt have simple ease, for thy love's pain.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Alas poor wench, I sorrow for thy hap,
To see how thou art clogged with such a dunce:
Forsooth my sire hath fitted me far better,
My Frenchman comes upon me with the sa, sa, sa;
sweet madam pardon moye I pray:
And then out goes his hand, down goes his head,
Swallows his spittle, frizzles his beard; and then to me:
Pardon moy mistress Mathea,
If I be bold, to macke so bold met you,
Think it go will dat spurs me dus up ye.
Dan cast neit off so good and true lover,
Madama celestura de la, (I know not what)
Do oft pray to God dat me would love her:
And then he reckons a catalogue of names
Of such as love him, and yet cannot get him.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nay, but your monsieur's but a mouse in cheese,
Compared with my signior; he can tell
Of lady Venus, and her son blind Cupid:
Of the fair Scylla that was loved of Glaucus,
And yet scorned Glaucus, and yet loved King Minos;
Yet Minos hated her, and yet she helped him;
And yet he scorned her, yet she killed her father
To do her good; yet he could not abide her:
Nay, he'll be bawdy too in his discourse;
And when he is so, he will take my hand,
And tickle the palm, wink with his one eye,
Gape with his mouth, and

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: And, hold thy tongue I prithee: here's my father.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Vandal, Delion, Harvey, Walgraue, and Heigham.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Unmannerly, untaught, unnurtured girls,
Do I bring gentlemen, my very friends
To feast with me, to revel at my house,
That their good likings, may be set on you,
And you like misbehaved and sullen girls,
Turn tail to such, as may advance your states:
I shall remember't, when you think I do not.
I am sorry gentlemen, your cheare's no better;
but what did want at board, excuse me for,
And you shall have amends be made in bed.
To them friends, to them; they are none but yours:
For you I bred them, for you brought them up:
For you I kept them, and you shall have them:
I hate all others that resort to them:
Then rouse your bloods ▪ be bold with what's your own:
For I and mine (My friends) be yours, or none.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: God-gee good-morrow sir, I have brought you m. mouse here to teach my young mistresses: I assure you (Forsooth) he is a brave Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Welcome friend, welcome: my man (I think)
Hath at the full, resolved thee of my will.
Monsieur Delion, I pray question him:
I tell you sir, 'tis only for your sake,
That I do mean to entertain this fellow,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A bots of all ill luck, how came these here?
Now am I posed except the wenches help me:
I have no French to flap them in the mouth,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: To see the luck of a good fellow, poor Anthony
Could ne'er have sorted out a worser time:
Now will the pack of all our sly devises
Be quite laid ope, as one undoes an oyster:
Francke, Heigham, and mad Ned, fall to your muses,
To help poor Anthony now at a pinch,
Or all our market will be spoilt and marred.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Tut man, let us alone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Monsieur, vous estes tresbien venu, de quell pais estes vous.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Vous, that's you: sure he says, how do men call you monsieur le mouche?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Sister, help sister; that's honest Anthony,
And he answers, your wooer cuius contrarium.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p:
Monsieur, vous n'entens pas, je ne demand puit,
vostre nom?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Monsieur Delion, he that made your shoes, made them not in fashion: they should have been cut square at the toe.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Madam, my sho met de square toe, vat be dat?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why saucebox; how now you unreverent minx
Why? in whose stable haste thou been brought up,
To interrupt a man in midst of speech?
Monsieur Delion, disquiet not yourself,
But as you have begun, I pray proceed
To question with this countryman of yours.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Dat me sal do tres beien, but de bella madonna de iune gentlewoman do monster some sing of amour to speak lot me, epurce monsieur, me sal say but two tree four five word to dir francois: or sus monsieur le mouche en quelle party de France esties vous ne?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: France.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Ned.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'Sblood, let me come.
Master Pisaro, we have occasion of affairs,
Which calls us hence with speed; wherefore I pray
Defer this business till some fitter time,
And to perform what at the exchange we spoke of.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: A blessing on that tongue, saith Anthony.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry gentlemen, I will, I will.
Alvaro to your task, fall to your task,
I'll bear away those three, who being here,
Would set my daughters on a merry pin:
Then cheerly try your lucks; but speak, and speed,
For you alone (Say I) shall do the deed.

div.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Haruy, Walgraue, and Higham.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Hear you m. mouse, did you dine today at Paul's with the rest of the gentlemen there?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: No sir, I am yet undined.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
methinks you should have a reasonable good
stomach then by this time, as for me I can sell nothing within me from my mouth to my codpiece but all empty, wherefore I think a piece of wisdom to go in and see what Maudlin hath provided for our dinner master mouse will you go in?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: With as good a stomach and desire as yourself.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Let's pass in then

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Han seg you dochtor, vor vat cause, voer why bede also much grooterlie strange, ic seg you wat, if datt ghy speak to me, is datt ghy love me.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.p: Is't that I care not for you, is't that your breath stinks, if that your breath stinks not, you must learn sweeter English or I shall never understand your suit.

sp.speaker: Delion.
sp.p: Pardon moy madame.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Withal my heart so you offend no more.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Is dat an offence to be amorous di one belle gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Ay sir see your belle gentlewoman cannot be amorous of you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then if I were as that belle gentlewoman's lover,
I would trouble her no further, nor be amorous any longer.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Madona yet de belleza of de face beauty deform of all de corpo may be such datt no perriculo, nor all de mal shaunce, can make him leave her dulce visage.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But signior Alvaro if the periculo or mal shaunce were such, that she should love and live with another, than the dulce visage must be left in spite of the lover's teeth, whilst he may whine at his own ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Datts waer matresse, for it is untrue saying, they wint he taught day verleift lie scrat sin gatt.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: And I think to are like to scratch there but never to claw any of my sister's love away.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p:
Dan sal your sistree do 'gainst her vaders will,
or your vader segt dat ick sal heb har vor mine wife.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: I think not so sir, for I never heard him say so ▪ but I'll go in and ask him if his meaning be so.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Hark sister signior Alvaro say, that I am the fairest of all us three,

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Believe him not for he'll tell any lie.
If so he thinks thou mayst be pleased thereby,
Come go with me and near stand prating here,
I have a jest to tell thee in thine ear,
Shall make you laugh: come let your signior stand,
I know there's not a wench in all this town,
Scoffs at him more, or loves him less than thou.
Master Vandal, as much I say for you;
If needs you marry with an English lass,
Woe her in English, or she'll call you ass.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Tut that's a French cog; sure I think,
There's ne'er a wench in France not half so fond,
To woe and sue so for your mounsership.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Par may foy madam, she does tincke dare is no wench so dure as you: for de fillee was cree dulce, tender, and amorous for me to love her; now me tincke dat I being such a fine man, you should lova me.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: So think not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: But so tincke esh oder damosellas.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Nay I'll lay my love to your command,
That my sisters think not so: how say you sister Mall?
Why how now gentlemen, is this your talk?
What beaten in plain field: where be your maids?
Nay then I see their loving humour fades,
And they resign their interest up to me;
And yet I cannot serve for all you three:
But least two should be mad, that I love one,
You shall be all alike, and I'll love none:
The world is scant, when so many Jack daws,
hover about one corse with greedy paws:
If needs you'll have me stay till I am dead,
Carrion for crows, Mathea for her Ned:
And so farewell, we sisters do agree,
To have our wills, but never to have you three.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Madama attendez, madama: is she all? do she mockque de nows in such sort?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: O de pestilence, no if datick can neite dese englese spreake vel, it shall her fader seg how dit is to pass gecomen.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Ne parlate, see here signors de fader.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Now friends, now gentlemen, how speeds your work; have you not found them shrewd unhappy girls?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Mester Pisaro, de dochter mistress Laurentia call me de dyel, den ass, for that ic can neit englesh spreken.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: And dat we sal no parlour, dat we sal no havar den for de wive.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Are they so lusty? Dare they be so proud?
Well, I shall find a time to meet with them:
In the mean season, pray frequent my house.
Ho now sirrah, whither are you running?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: About a little tiny business.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What business, ass?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Indeed I was not sent to you: and yet I was sent after the three gen-men that dined here, to bid them come to our house at ten o'clock at night, when you were a-bed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, what is this? Can this be true?
What, art thou sure the wenches bade them come?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: So they said, unless their minds be changed since: for a woman is like a weathercock they say, and I am sure of no more than I am certain of: but I'll go in and bid them send you word, whether they shall come or no.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: No sirrah, stay you here; but one word more: did they appoint them come one by one, or else all together?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Altogether: lord that such a young man as you should have no more wit: why if they should come together, one could not make room for them; but coming one by one, they'll stand there if there were twenty of them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How this news glads me, and revives my soul: how say you sirs, what will you have a jest worth the telling; nay worth the acting: I have it gentlemen, I have it friends.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signior Pisaro, I pray de gratia watte maneire sal we have? what will the parlour? what bon do you know signior Pisaro, dicheti noi signior Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: O that youth so sweet, so soon should turn to age; were I as you, why this were sport alone for me to do.
sp.l: Hark ye, hark ye; here my man,
Saith, that the girls have sent for master Heigham
And his two friends; I know they love them dear,
And therefore wish them late at night be here
To revel with them: will you have a jest,
To work my will, and give your longings rest:
Why then m. Vandal, and you two,
Shall soon at midnight come, as they should do,
And court the wenches; and to be unknown,
And taken for the men, whom they alone
So much affect; each one shall change his name:
Master Vandal, you shall take Heigham, and you
Young Harvey, and monsieur Delion Ned,
And under shadows be of substance sped:
How like you this device? how think you of it?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: O de brave de galliard device: me sal come by de night and contier fair de anglois gentlehomes dictenous ainsi monsieur Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: You are in the right sir.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: And I sall name me de signior Haruy, end monsicur Delion sall be de piculo signior Ned, end when madonna Laurentia sall say, who be dare? mister Vandal sall say, o my sout laid, hire be your love mestro Heigham: is no dis de bravissime, master Vandal?

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.l: Slact up den tromele, van ick sall come
Up to de camerken, won my new wincken
Slact up den tromele, van ick sall come.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, master Vandal,
I trow you will be merry soon at night,
When you shall do in deed, what now you hope of.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: I sall v seg vader, ick sall tesh your daughter such a ting, make her laugh too.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well my sons all, (For so I count you shall)
What we have here devised, provide me for:
But above all, do not (I pray) forget
To come but one by one, as they did wish.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Mar hortens vader, ick veite neite de wecke to your houis, hort ens sall master frisco your manneken come to call de me, and bring me to v house.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry shall he: see that you be ready,
And at the hour of eleven soon at night:
Hie you to Bucklersbury to his chamber,
And so direct him straight unto my house:
My son Alvaro, and monsieur Delion,
I know, doth know the way exceeding well:
Well, we'll to the rose in Barken for an hour:
And sirrah Frisco, see you prove no blab.

div.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandal.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
O monstrous, who would think my master had so much wit in his old rotten budget: and yet i'fath he is not much troubled with it neither. Why what wise man in a kingdom would send me for the Dutchman? Does he think I'll not cozen him: o fine, I'll
have the bravest sport: o brave, I'll have the gallentest sport: o come; now if I can hold behind, while I may laugh a while, I care not: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Why how now Frisco, why laughest thou so heartily?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Laugh m. mouse: laugh, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho
sp.p: Laugh, why should I laugh? or why art thou so merry?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O master mouse, master mouse, it would make any mouse, rat, cat, or dog, laugh to think, what sport we shall have at our house soon at night: I'll tell you, all, my young mistresses sent me after m. Heigham and his friends, to pray them come to our house after my old master was a-bed : now I went, and I went; and I run, and I went: and whom should I meet, but my master and m. Pisaro and the strangers; so my master very worshipfully (I must needs say) examined me whither I went now? I durst not tell him an untruth, for fear of lying, but told him plainly and honestly mine errand: now who would think my master had such a monstrous plaguy wit, he was as glad as could be; out of all scotch and notch glad, out of all count glad? and so sirrah he bid the three uplandish-men come in their steads and woe my young mistresses: now it made me so laugh to think how they will be cozened, that I could not follow my master: but I'll follow him, I know he is gone to the tavern in his merry humour: now if you will keep this as secret as I have done hitherto, we shall have the bravest sport soon, as can be. I must be gone, say nothing.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well it is so:
And we will have good sport, or it shall go hard;
This must the wenches know, or all is marred.
Hark you mist. Moll, mist.Laurentia, mistressMatt,
I have such news (My girls) will make you smile.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: What be they master, how I long to hear it?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A woman right, still longing, and with child,
For every thing they hear, or light upon:
Well ▪ if you be mad wenches, hear it now,
Now may your knaveries give the deadliest blow
To night-walkers, eavese-droppers, or outlandish love,
That ere was stristen.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Anthony Mowche,
Move but the matter; tell us but the jest,
And if you find us slack to execute,
Never give credence, or believe us more.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Then know: the strangers your outlandish loves,
Appointed by your father, comes this night
In stead of Harvey, Heigham, and young Ned,
Under their shadows to get to your bed:
For Frisco simply told him why he went:
I need not to instruct, you can conceive,
You are not stocks nor stones, but have some store
Of wit and knavery too.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Anthony, thanks
Is too too small a guerdon for this news;
You must be English: well sir signior souse,
I'll teach you tricks for coming to our house.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Are you so crafty, o that night were come,
That I might hear my Dutchman how he'd swear
In his own mother language, that he loves me:
Well, if I quit him not, I here pray God,
I may lead apes in hell, and die a maid;
And that were worser to me then a hanging.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well said old honest huddles; here's a heap
Of merry lasses: well, for myself,
I'll hie me to your lovers, bid them mask
With us at night, and in some corner stay
Near to our house, where they may make some play
Upon your rivals, and when they are gone,
come to your windows.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Do so good master.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Peace, begone; for this our sport,
Somebody soon will mourn.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How favourable heaven and earth is seen,
To grace the mirthful complot that is laid,
Night's candles burn obscure, and the pale moon
Favouring our drift, lies buried in a cloud:
I can but smile to see the simple girls,
Hoping to have their sweethearts hear tonight ,
Tickled with extreme joy, laugh in my face:
But when they find, the strangers in their steads,
They'll change their note, and sing another song.
Where be these girls here? what, to bed, to bed:
Maudlin make fast the doors, rake up the fire;
Gods me, 'tis nine o'clock , hark bow-bell rings:Knock.
Some look down below, and see who knocks:
And hark you girls, settle your hearts at rest,
And full resolve you, that tomorrow morn,
You must be wed to such as I prefer;
I mean Alvaro and his other friends:
Let me no more be troubled with your nays.
You shall do what I'll have, and so resolve.
Welcome m. Moore, welcome,
What wind a-gods name drives you forth so late?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Faith sir, I am come to trouble you,
My wife this present night is brought to bed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: To bed, and what hath God sent you?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: A jolly girl, sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: And God bless her: but what's your will sir?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Faith sir, my house being full of friends,
Such as (I thank them) came to see my wife?
I would request you, that for this one night,
My daughter Susan might be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lodge in my house, welcome withal my heart,
Matt hark you, she shall lie with you,
Trust me she could not come in fitter time.
For hear you sir, tomorrow in the morning.
All my three daughters must be married,
Good master Moore let's have your company,
What say you sir; welcome honest friend.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: How now sirrah what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Mowche hear you, stir betimes tomorrow,
For then I mean your scholars shall be wed:
What news, what news man that you look so sad,

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: He brings me word my wife is new fallen sick,
And that my daughter cannot come tonight :
Or if she does, it will be very late.

sp.speaker: Pisa,
sp.l: Believe me I am then more sorry for it.
But for your daughter come she soon or late,
Some of us will be up to let her in,
For here be three means not to sleep tonight :
Well you must be gone? commend me to your wife,
Take heed how you go down, the stairs are bad,
Bring here a light.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: 'Tis well I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Good night master Moore farewell honest friend,
Come, come to bed, to bed 'tis nine and past,
Do not stand prating here to make me fetch you,
But get you to your chambers. Exit Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: By’r lady here's short work, hark you girls,
Will you tomorrow marry with the strangers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Y faith sir no I'll first leap out at window,
Before Marina marry with a stranger,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes but your father swears, you shall have one.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes but his daughters, swears they shall have none,
these whoreson cannibals, these Philistines,
These tango-mongoes shall not rule o'er me,
I'll have my will and Ned, or I'll have none.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: How will you get him? how will you get him?
I know no other way except it be this,
That when your fathers in his soundest sleep,
You open the door and run away with them,

sp.speaker: All sisters.
sp.p: So we will rather then miss of them.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: 'Tis well resolved i'fath and like yourselves,
But hear you? to your chambers presently,
Lest that your father do descry our drift,Exeunt sisters.
Mistress Susan should come but she cannot,
Nor perhaps shall not, yet perhaps she shall,
Might not a man conceit a pretty jest?
And make as mad a riddle as this is,
If all things fadge not, as all things should do,
We shall be sped i'faith, Matt shall have hue.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Wear be you mester Frisco.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Here sir, here sir, now if I could cozen him, take heed sir hers a post.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ick be so groterly hot, datt ick sweat, o wen sal we come dare.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Be you so hot sir, let me carry your cloak, I assure you it will ease you much.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Dare here, dare, 'tis so dark eye can neit see.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Ay, so so: now you may travel in your hose and doublet: now look I as like the Dutchman, as if I were spit out of his mouth: I'll straight home, and speak groote and brood, and toot and gibberish; and in the dark I'll have a fling at the wenches. Well, I say no more; farewell m. Mendall, I must go seek my fortune.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p:
Mester Frisco, mester Frisco, wat sal you no speak; make you de fool? Why mester Frisco; o de skellum,
he be given met de cloak, me sal seg his mester, han mester frisco, waer sidy mester frisco.

sp.speaker: Haruy.
sp.l: Goes the case so well signior bottlenose ▪
It may be we shall overreach your drift;
This is the time the wenches sent us word
Our bombast Dutchman and his mates will come.
Well neat Italian, you must don my shape:
Play your part well, or I may haps pay you.
What, speechless Ned? faith whereon musest thou?
'Tis on your French corrival, for my life:
He come eat vostre, and so forth,
Till he hath foisted in a brat or two?
How then, how then?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'Swounds I'll geld him first,
Ere that incestuous lozel revel there.
Well Matt, I think thou knowest what Ned can do;
Shouldst thou change Ned for noddy, me for him,
Thou didst not know thy loss, i'fath thou didst not.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come leave this idle chat, and let's provide
Which of us shall be scarecrow to these fools,
And set them out the way?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Why that will I.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Then put a sword into a madman's hand:
Thou art so hasty, that but cross thy humour,
And thou'lt be ready cross them o'er the pates:
Therefore for this time, I'll supply the room.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And so we shall be sure of chat enough;
You'll hold them with your flouts and gulls so long,
That all the night will scarcely be enough
To put in practice, what we have devised:
Come, come, I'll be the man shall do the deed.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Well, I am content to save your longing.
But soft, where are we? Ha, here's the house,
come let us take our stands: France stand you there,
And Ned and I will cross tother side.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Do so: but hush, I hear one passing hither.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: O de favourable aspect of de heaven, 'tis so obscure, so dark, so black dat no mortal creature can know de me: I pray a dio I sal have de reight wench: ah si I be recht, here be de huis of signior Pisaro, I sall have de madonna Marina, and darvor I sall knock to de door.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a pox are you mad or drunk;
What, do you mean to break my glasses?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wat be dat glass? Wat drunk, what mad?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What glasses sir; why my glasses: and if you be so crank, I'll call the constable; you will not enter into a man's house (I hope) in spite of him?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Nor durst you be so bold as to stand there,
If once the master of the house did know it.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Is dit your house? be you de signior of dis cassa?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Signior me no signors, nor cassa me no cassas: but get you hence, or you are like to taste of the bastinado.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Do, do, good Ferdinand, pummel the loggerhead.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Is this neit the house of mester Pisaro?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Yes marry when? can you tell: how do you?
I thank you heartily, my finger in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wat be dat?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry that you are an ass and a loggerhead,
To seek master Pisaro's house here.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: I pray de gratia, what be dis plash?
Wat do ye call dit street?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What sir; why leaden-hall, could you not see the four spouts as you came along?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Certenemento Leden hall, I hit my head by de way, dare may be de voer spouts: I pray de gratia, wish be de weigh to Crochefriers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: How, to croched-friers? Marry you must go along till you come to the pump, and then turn on your right hand.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signior, adio.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Farewell and be hanged signior:
Now for your fellow, if the ass would come.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: By my trot me do so much tincke of dit gentlewoman de fine wenshe, dat me tincke esh hover ten day, and esh day ten year, till I come to her: here be de huise of sin vader, sall all and knock. He knocks.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a bot's ail you, are you mad?
Will you run over me and break my glasses?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Glasses, what glasses? Pray is monsieur Pisaro to de mayson?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Hark Ned, there's thy substance

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay by the mass, the substance's here,
The shadow's but an ass.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What master Pisaro?
Loggerhead, here's none of your Pisaro's?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Yes but dit is the houis of mester Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Will not this monsieur motley take his answer?
I'll go and knock the ass about the pate.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay by your leave sir, but I'll hold your worship.
This stir we should have had, had you stood there.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Why, would it not vex one to hear the ass,
Stand prating here of dit and dan, and den and dog?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: One of thy mettle Ned, would surely do it:
But peace, and hark to the rest.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Do no de fine gentlewoman matresse Mathea dwell in dit plash?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: No sir, here dwells none of your fine gentlewoman ▪ 'twere a good deed sirrah, to see who you are;
sp.l: You come hither to steal my glasses.
And then counterfeit you are going to your queans.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: I be deceu dis dark neight; here be no wenshe, I be no in de right plash: I pray monsieur, what be name dis street, and wish be de way to croshe-friers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry this is Fanchurch-street,
And the best way to crotched-friers, is to follow your nose

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Vanshe, street, how shaunce me come to Vanshe street? vell monsieur, me must all to crochefriers.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Farewell fortipence, go seek your signior,
I hope you'll find yourselves two dolts anon:
Hush Ferdinand, I hear the last come stamping hither.

sp.speaker: Frise.
sp.p: Ha sirrah, I have left my fat Dutchman, and run myself almost out of breath too: now to my young mistresses go I, somebody cast an old shoe after me: but soft, how shall I do to counterfeit the Dutchman, be cause I speak English so like a natural; tush, take you no thought for that, let me alone for squintum squantum: soft, here's my master's house,

sp.speaker: High.
sp.p: Who's there.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Who's there, why sir here is: nay that's too good English; why here be de growtte Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Then there's not only a grout head, but an ass also.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What be you, you be an English ox to call a gentle moan ass.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Hark Ned yonder's good greeting.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: But you, and you be master mouse that dwell here, tell your matressa Laurentia datt her sweet heart master Vandal would speak with horde,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Master Mendall, get you gone, lest you get a broken pate and so mar all: here's no entrance for mistress laurentios sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Gods sacaren watt is the luck now.
Shall not I come to my friend master Pisar Hoose?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Yes and to master Pisaro's shoes too, if he or they were here.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why my grout friend, m. Pisaro doth dwell here.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Sirrah, you lie, here dwells nobody but I, that have dwelled here this one and forty years, and sold glasses.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Lie farther, one and fifty at the least.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoo, ho, ho; do you give the gentleman the lie?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Ay sir, and will give you a lick of my cudgel, if ye stay long and trouble the whole street with your bawling: hence dolt, and go seek m. Pisaro's house.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Go seek m. Pisaro's house;
Where shall I go seek it?

sp.speaker: Hegh.
sp.p: Why, you shall go seek it where it is.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: That is here in crodched-friers.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: How loggerhead, is croched-friers here?
I thought you were some such drunken ass,
That come to seek croched-friers in tower-street:
But get you along on your left hand, and be hanged;
You have kept me out of my bed with your bangling,
A good while longer than I would have been.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Ah, ah, how is this? Is not this croched-friers? Tell me, I'll hold a crown they gave me so much wine at the tavern, that I am drunk, and know not out.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: My Dutchman's out his compass and his card;
He's reckoning what wind hath driven him hither:
I'll swear he thinks never to see Pisaro's.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay 'tis so, I am sure drunk: soft let me see, what was I about?
